question: A basic 2D RNAV system will determine tracking information from:
explanation:
A simple RNAV system uses rho/theta (range/bearing) to define position, which is derived from range and bearing information from VOR/DME stations.

 

A common general aviation RNAV system is the track-line computer (TLC), based on azimuth and distance information from a VORTAC. It is also called the RHO-THETA system. With the track-line computer the pilot effectively moves or off-sets the VORTAC to any desired location if it is within reception range.

This “phantom station” is created by setting the distance (RHO) and the bearing (THETA) of the waypoint from a convenient VORTAC in the appropriate windows of the waypoint selector. A series of these “phantom stations” or waypoints make up an RNAV route.
subject: Radio Navigation

question: The FMC position will be at its most inaccurate:
explanation: The 737 manual quotes that the FMC position should be considered to be the most inaccurate at TOD. the FMC position will be least accurate the longer the time the a/c is out of radio updating range (no GPS input), like in this case
subject: Radio Navigation

question: The accuracy required of a precision area navigation system is:
explanation:
There are two types of RNAV:

Basic RNAV (B-RNAV) which is required to give a position accuracy to within 5 nm on 95% of occasions. It is now mandatory for all aircraft carrying 30 passengers or more to have B-RNAV capability within Euro-control airspace.

Precision RNAV (P-RNAV) must be accurate to within 1.0 nm on 95% of occasions. P-RNAV routes are now being established in terminal airspace.
subject: Radio Navigation

question: The IRS position can be updated:

choices.choice: at designated positions en-route and on the ground
on the ground and overhead VOR/DME
at selected waypoints and on the ground

explanation:
The aircraft must not be moved during levelling and alignment

 

If the aircraft is stationary on the ground then only we can update the irs

FMC position is updated inflight not the IRS position
subject: Radio Navigation

question: Concerning FMC operation, which of the following is true:

choices.choice: the FMC combines the long term accuracy of the IRS with the short term accuracy of the external reference
the FMC combines the long term accuracy of the IRS with the long term accuracy of the external reference
the FMC combines the short term accuracy of the IRS with the short term accuracy of the external reference
the FMC combines the short term accuracy of the IRS with the long term accuracy of the external reference

subject: Radio Navigation

question: The correct format for the input of position 50N 00527E to the CDU is:
explanation: Latitude and Longitude as either a 7 group alphanumeric (e.g. N05W010) or a 15 group (e.g. N0926.3W00504.7) Note the leading zeros must be entered for the FMC to accept the position.
subject: Radio Navigation

question: The period of validity of the navigational database is:

choices.choice: determined by the national authority and may be from 28 days to 91 days

explanation:
The navigation data is updated every 28 days and the FMC contains the current and next 28 days database (this coincides with the ICAO navigation data cycle). The data may be customised for the specific airline operations.

no external data can be uploaded by pilots,  navigational data can be INSERTED but not UPDATED
subject: Radio Navigation

question: The sequence of displays accessed on initialisation is:
explanation:
First IDENT PAGE

When power is applied, the FMS executes an internal test sequence. When the test is successfully completed, it presents the IDENT page on the CDU. This page contains information on the aircraft model and engine thrust from the performance database

SECOND POSITION INITIALISATION  PAGE

The position initialisation (POS INIT) page allows initialisation of heading and position for the IRS.

 

THIRD ROUTE PAGE

The route pages are used to insert, check and/or modify a company route, or to insert a route not held in the database.

remember I,P,R
subject: Radio Navigation

question: Above latitudes of 84° a twin FMS/triple IRS system will go to de-coupled operations. The reason for this is:

choices.choice: to prevent error messages as the IRS longitudes show large differences
because the magnetic variation changes rapidly in high latitudes

explanation: When operating at latitudes in excess of 84° the FMC will de-couple the IRS with the left FMC using the IRS in the order left, centre, right and the right FMC in the order right, centre, left. Over a short period of time each FMC will change the FMC position to the appropriate IRS position. The reason for the de-coupling is that the calculation of change of longitude from departure is a function of the secant of latitude, which, at values approaching 90°, is increasing rapidly (e.g. sec 86°00 = 14.3356, sec 86°01′ = 14.3955). This means that a small error in latitude will result in a large error in the calculation of change of longitude. This would give an apparent large divergence between the IRS positions in terms of the longitude calculated, although in fact the actual difference in position would be small.
subject: Radio Navigation

question: Refer to Appendix A. What are the correct selections to insert the most accurate position into the IRS?
explanation: At 4R the FMC is asking for the aircraft position to initialise the IRS. The position could be input manually in the scratchpad then inserted by selecting 4R. However, the database has already inserted the position into 3R, so this can be copied by selecting 3R to draw the data down to the scratchpad and then 4R to insert into the field.
subject: Radio Navigation

question: The maximum range at which VOR bearing information will be used by the B737-400 FMC for fixing is:
subject: Radio Navigation

question: Which positions can be input to the FMC using a maximum of 5 alpha-numerics?

choices.choice: SIDS & STARS, reporting points and airways designators
Navigation facilities, reporting points and airways designators
SIDS & STARS and latitude and longitude
Latitude and longitude, reporting points and airways designators

explanation:
Up to 5 alphanumerics for ICAO aerodrome designators, reporting points, navigation facilities, airways designators (e.g. VIDP, IBANI,DPN,DIG) and runway desigantors

Up to 7 alphanumerics for SID and STAR (e.g. BUTOP5B)
subject: Radio Navigation

question: The FMC navigational database can be accessed by the pilots:

choices.choice: to change information between the 28 day updates
to change the information to meet the sector requirements

explanation:
The navigation data is updated every 28 days and the FMC contains the current and next 28 days database (this coincides with the ICAO navigation data cycle). The data may be customised for the specific airline operations.

no external data can be uploaded by pilots,  navigational data can be INSERTED but not UPDATED
subject: Radio Navigation

question: An aircraft using a basic 2D RNAV system is on a section between WP1 and WP2, a distance of 45 nm. The aircraft is 20nm from the phantom station, which is 270°/30 nm from the VOR/DME. The aircraft is 15nm from the VOR/DME. The range readout will show:
explanation: Since there are only two range readouts VOR/DME or the Phantom station aircraft will read out the Phantom station which is 20 nautical mile because it is navigating using 2D RNAV system not the VOR/DME ,  phantom station has been created using the bearing and distance from a vor /dme station ,
subject: Radio Navigation

question: The position used by the FMC in the B737-400 is:

choices.choice: an average of the two IRS positions
an average of the two IRS positions, smoothed by the Kalman filtering process.
taken from the selected IRS, smoothed by Kalman filtering and updated to the external reference
generated from the external reference and updated by the IRS as part of the Kalman filtering process.

explanation: Kalman filtering is the process used within a navigation computer to combine the short term accuracy of the IRS with the long term accuracy of the external reference
subject: Radio Navigation
